title: Bangladesh: 16 people sentenced to death over murder of student
text:
Nusrat Jahan Rafi was set on fire after refusing to withdraw sexual harassment allegation

A court in Bangladesh has sentenced 16 people to death over the murder of a 19-year-old student who was burned alive.

Nusrat Jahan Rafi was doused in paraffin and set on fire in April after refusing to withdraw a sexual harassment complaint against the headteacher of the seminary she attended.

Speaking after the verdict was announced in the high court, the prosecutor, Hafez Ahmed, said: “The verdict proves that nobody will get away with murder in Bangladesh. We have the rule of law.”

Rafi was lured to the roof of the seminary, where her attackers pressed her to withdraw the complaint she had filed with the police. When she refused, she was tied up and set on fire.

She sustained burns to 80% of her body and died in hospital five days later on 10 April.

Her death caused outrage and highlighted an alarming rise in sexual harassment cases.

Protesters in the Bangladeshi capital, Dhaka, demonstrated for several days, seeking “exemplary punishment” for the killers.

Sheikh Hasina, the prime minister, promised to prosecute all those involved.

Rafi had gone to police in late March to report sexual harassment, and a leaked video showed a police chief registering her complaint but dismissing it as “not a big deal”.

At the time, police had said one of the 18 people initially arrested had accused the school’s principal of ordering the attack.

Supt Mohammad Iqbal, who led the police investigation, said the headteacher told them to put pressure on Rafi to withdraw the case and kill her if she refused.

Iqbal also said some of those arrested were Rafi’s classmates and they had tied her up with a scarf before setting her on fire.

“The plan was to pass the incident off as a suicide. But it fell through after Rafi managed to come downstairs while on fire because the scarf burnt and freed her hands and feet,” he said.

Activists said the murder exposed a culture of impunity around sexual crimes against women and children, and the risks of reporting harassment.

Prosecutions are also rare in cases of rape and sexual assault. After the killing, Bangladesh ordered 27,000 schools to set up committees to prevent sexual violence.

Defence lawyers said they would appeal against the verdict. The case was fast-tracked, with the hearing taking 62 days.
